---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

- [x] depends on: #16011

nodes.body: messageFile.md

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#16011~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

1. In Gonthier's 4CT Coq proof combinatorial maps are called hypermaps and their three permutations are called `edge, node, face` in that order. I believe this is a more appropriate name as _none_ of the three permutations has to be an involution, whereas combinatorial maps as defined elsewhere may have the involution restriction.
2. Don't use `.trans`, `.comp` and the like; use `*`!
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
messageFile.md

Good start, thanks for working on this!

I wonder if it's worth trying to prove something non-trivial with this API first? Right now I don't have an idea how usable this is, and having an example would help with that.

Good start, thanks for working on this!

I wonder if it's worth trying to prove something non-trivial with this API first? Right now I don't have an idea how usable this is, and having an example would help with that.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simp? ```
eulerCharacteristic

Can we call these fields `vertex`, `edge`, and `face`? Or some similar word, like `vertices` or `vertexPerm` etc.

Usually we use single Greek letters for type variables.

IIRC, in the Coq version, the three perms are declared as normal functions, and the fact that they are permutations is derived from `composition`. Can we do that here?

Alternatively, since any one perm is fixed by the other two, we can _define_ one of them that way, and then the `composition` property is redundant.

Great idea, but how should we implement it? Permutations are not a class, I cannot say something such as `instance : Perm D vertexPerm` where `vertexPerm : D â†’ D` right?
One idea is to define `CombinatorialMap` as following:
```lean
/--
A two-dimension combinatorial map is a collection `D` of darts, and maps `vertexMap`, `edgeMap`, and
`edgeMap`. `edgeMap` is a fixed-point-free involution.

Note: this definition excludes disjoint isolated vertices.
-/
structure CombinatorialMap (D : Type*) where
  /--
  Map whose orbits correspond to vertices, it gives the next dart counter-clockwise around an edge.
  -/
  vertexMap : D â†’ D
  /-- Map whose orbits correspond to edges, it gives the opposite dart of an edge. -/
  edgeMap : D â†’ D
  /--
  Map whose orbits correspond to faces, it gives the next dart counter-clockwise of the same face.
  -/
  faceMap : D â†’ D
  edgeMap_vertexMap_faceMap_eq_id : edgeMap âˆ˜ vertexMap âˆ˜ faceMap = id
  edgeMap_involutive : edgeMap.Involutive
  isEmpty_fixedPoints_edgeMap : IsEmpty (Function.fixedPoints edgeMap)
  ```
  And then have separate permutations in the `CombinatorialMap` namespace as follows:
  ```lean
  def edgePerm : Equiv.Perm D where
  toFun := M.edgeMap
  invFun := M.edgeMap
  left_inv := M.edgeMap_involutive
  right_inv := M.edgeMap_involutive
  ```
  And so on for the rest of the maps. Is this solution satisfactory or do you have other ideas?
This should be named `edgePerm_involutive` or similar, because it's not the whole map that is involutive, just the edge permutation.
isEmpty_fixedPoints_vertexPerm

Thank you for the valuable review and sorry for taking so long to address it.
Did you mean `isEmpty_fixedPoints_edgePerm` here or is it a part of the definition that the vertex permutation has no fixed points?
Instead of defining `composition`, `composition'`, etc., consider using a more literal name like `vertex_mul_edge_mul_face`.

This feels unidiomatic to me. Can we bundle the `f` into the structure, like we do for `SimpleGraph.Hom`?

We can define a separate `Iso` that is bijective.

dual_dual

And I don't think this needs a doc comment.
Names of types should be uppercase and singular.
Function application binds tightly, so we don't need the parentheses here.
I think it makes more sense to call this `Vertex.mk`. Similarly for the edges and faces.

Use `Set.preimage`.

Or, since nothing uses this definition yet, we can delete it and have users write `M.dartVertex â»Â¹' {v}` themselves.

pullRequest.title: feat: combinatorial maps and planar graphs
